citeinfo.origin: Samuel W. Flake, North Carolina State University
citeinfo.title: Projected habitat for birds of conservation concern in the southern Appalachians, from 2020-2100

descript.abstract:
This dataset provides projections for future occurrence of several bird species of conservation concern, for the southern Appalachians of SC, GA, NC, TN, VA, and KY. Predictions were created from a LANDIS-II simulation model linked to a species distribution model. SDMs were trained on eBird data and using a suite of topographic, climatic, and vegetation variables, including spaceborne LiDAR. The LANDIS-II model was parameterized using inventory data, soils, topography, and species trait data.
The LANDIS-II model was run for 80 years using two climate scenarios. Each 10 years, vegetation and climate data was output from the LANDIS-II model and used generate predictions from the SDM. Three sets of predictions were created: a "full" prediction using all of the variables; a "clim" prediction that holds climate constant (i.e., uses year-0 climate) and vegetation data from the present timestep; and "veg" prediction that holds vegetation constant (i.e. year-0 vegetation state) with varying climate. There are five replicate runs for each climate scenario.
The naming convention is as follows: type of prediction _ species _ climate scenario _ management scenario _ replicate _ timestep
For example, clim_predictions_acfl_HighTHighV BAU - Run1_30 refers to the "clim_predictions" that keep climate constant, for Alder Flycatcher, for the HadGEM2 ES365 RCP 8.5 climate scenario. It is from the first replicate model run (Run1), and data from timestep 30 (i.e., year 2050).
descript.purpose: The data represent outcomes of a simulation modeling study to assess climate vulnerability of bird species of greatest conservation need in the southern Appalachians.

idinfo.accconst: No access constraints. Please see 'Distribution Information' for details.
idinfo.useconst: These data are marked with a Creative Common CC0 1.0 Universal License. These data are in the public domain and do not have any use constraints. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

attracc.attraccr: Accuracy was evaluated using cross-validated AUC (area under the curve of the receiver operating characteristic curve).

dataqual.logic: Predicted encounter rates range between 0 and 1, and visually align with expected species ranges. Data are statistically correlated with other bird distribution products (BBS, Climate Change Bird Atlas, eBird Status and Trends)
dataqual.complete: The data represent encounter rates fit for climate data from 2023 and vegetation data from 2014-2023, depending upon the data product.

citeinfo.title: Species distribution models for Appalachian bird species of conservation concern, circa 2023

srcinfo.srccontr: Species distribution models used to create predicted habitat index

procstep.procdesc:
Create SDMs
For each species, we fit species distribution models (SDMs) using boosted regression trees and a suite of remotely sensed datasets and publicly available data sources. Our models were trained on eBird data for Bird Conservation Region 28 from 2013-2023. eBird data were spatially and temporally thinned to 1.7 km and two weeks between checklists in order to prevent overrepresentation of species hotspots. Absences were randomly selected from eBird checklists such that our final dataset had an equal number of presences and absences. The number of observations used was limited to 5000 presences, randomly chosen from the reduced set of checklists. For more details on the SDM process, see Flake et al. (unpublished ms).

Creating LANDIS-II predictions
We used the LANDIS-II landscape change model framework (Scheller et al. 2007) to make projections of future vegetation across the southern Appalachians. LANDIS-II projects vegetation change as a function of climate, disturbance, and human activity. It is a non-equilibrium, stochastic model that is initialized with a ‘snapshot’ (or ‘digital twin’) of current vegetation conditions, including tree species and their ages and distributions, from which various processes (succession, competition, dispersal, disturbance, forest management) alter the composition and structure of vegetation over time. LANDIS-II includes the capacity for climate to influence these processes as appropriate. We built upon previous forecasts of forest change in the southern Appalachians (Robbins 2022, Robbins 2024). Robbins et al. (2024) included forest succession (via the NECN extension), wildfire (via the Social-Climate-Fire extension), and harvesting (via the Biomass Harvesting). Detailed information on parameterization can be found in Robbins et al. (2024).
We ran each model using initial conditions as described in Robbins et al. (2024), using two climate futures. HadGEM represents a high-warming scenario with high interannual variation in drought conditions, while MRI-CGM represents a scenario with less warming and little interannual variation in drought. In past analyses, this difference in climate trajectories resulted in dramatic differences in fire regimes, with potential knock-on impacts on bird habitat.

Crosswalk LANDIS-II to SDMs
Because the structure of LANDIS-II sites and cohorts differs from the input data we used for our SDMs, we developed models to crosswalk some LANDIS-II variables to counterparts in the SDM model to generate forecasts. For several variables, we developed regression equations to crosswalk the LANDIS-II initial communities to Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) data (Burrill et al., 2021) data from SC, GA, NC, TN, VA, and KY. We developed power-law regressions relating tree cohort age, species, and biomass to tree heights using the FIA SITETREE table, following previous work (Boardman et al., 2025). These regressions had fairly good fit, with coefficients of determination typically > 0.3, ranging from 0.14 to 0.55. Using these equations, we estimated cohort heights from their ages and species and then calculated RH98 as the 98th percentile of estimated cohort heights, FHD as the Shannon entropy of binned cohort heights, whether a site was “open” or not using tree heights and modeled LAI. We mapped these derived variables onto the LANDIS-II study area, and sampled 10,000 cells from both the LANDIS-II surface and the SDM training surfaces derived from remote sensing data for comparison.

attr.attrdef: Habitat index (class-balanced encounter rate) predicted from LANDIS-II simulation model and species distribution model

edom.edomvd: Not modeled (inactive cells), either outside study area or non-forested

overview.eaover:
The LANDIS-II model was run for 80 years using two climate scenarios. Each 10 years, vegetation and climate data was output from the LANDIS-II model and used generate predictions from the SDM. Three sets of predictions were created: a "full" prediction using all of the variables; a "clim" prediction that holds climate constant (i.e., uses year-0 climate) and vegetation data from the present timestep; and "veg" prediction that holds vegetation constant (i.e. year-0 vegetation state) with varying climate. There are five replicate runs for each climate scenario.
The naming convention is as follows: type of prediction _ species _ climate scenario _ management scenario _ replicate _ timestep
For example, clim_predictions_acfl_HighTHighV BAU - Run1_0 refers to the "clim_predictions" that keep climate constant, for Alder Flycatcher, for the HadGEM2 ES365 RCP 8.5 climate scenario.
HighTHighV refers to HadGEM2; LowTLowV refers to MRI-GCCM3
Raster files are identified by a four-letter banding code for species.
Banding codes for study species are as follows:
Species Scientific name Banding code
Acadian flycatcher Empidonax virescens ACFL Alder flycatcher Empidonax alnorum ALFL Blackburnian warbler Setophaga fusca BLBW Black-capped chickadee Poecile atricapillus BCCH Blue-winged warbler Vermivora cyanoptera BWWA Brown-headed nuthatch Sitta pusilla BHNU Cerulean warbler Setophaga cerulea CERW Eastern whip-poor-will Antrostomus vociferus EWPW Golden-winged warbler Vermivora chrysoptera GWWA Hermit thrush Catharus guttatus HETH Kentucky warbler Geothlypis formosa KEWA Louisiana waterthrush Parkesia motacilla LOWA Nashville warbler Leiothlypis ruficapilla NAWA Northern saw-whet owl Aegolius acadicus NSWO Olive-sided flycatcher Contopus cooperi OSFL Ovenbird Seiurus aurocapilla OVEN Prairie warbler Setophaga discolor PRAW Protonotary warbler Protonotaria citrea PROW Red crossbill Loxia curvirostra RECR Ruffed grouse Bonasa umbellus RUGR Swainson’s warbler Limnothlypis swainsonii SWWA Veery Catharus fuscescens VEER Wood thrush Hylocichla mustelina WOTH Worm-eating warbler Helmitheros vermivorus WEWA Yellow-throated warbler Setophaga dominica YTWA

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes, nor on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
